ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to read and understand scientific papers, write grant proposals and think like a scientist!

In taking this course I developed many applicable skills in relation to working in the scientific field. I learned how to evaluate scientific research papers and journals. I learned how to write a grant proposal, and craft presentations. I also learned how to think like a scientist.
I learned how to read scientific papers, understand basic biological techniques, and present scientific information clearly and concisely.
Analyzing scientific papers, effective presentation skills, and writing a grant proposal.
Reading and understanding biological research papers, particularly regarding COVID-19

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: A strength is the amount of knowledge gained throughout the course and the collaboration it promotes. While you have to input a lot of hours in this class, I don't think there is a weakness in this course.
The strengths of this course are its specificity, interaction, group work, and material. Weaknesses are really just the stressful workload.

The course strongly encouraged independent learning, which was difficult to adapt to but a necessary skill that made me a more productive student. However, I think the course would improve by a little less independent learning by incorporating more lectures from Dean Chang - especially on the technical information discussed in papers. Some students already had background in these areas but for those who didn't, it was difficult to keep up and hard to advocate for oneself.

Strengths: Massive volume of totally new knowledge learned over the semester, I definitely feel that I have a leg up over other biology majors.

Weaknesses: The format of the course this semester was a little odd (students presenting to each other every week, Dean Chang lectured only a few times) and office hours became irregular at the end of the semester.

Strengths: Very engaged class, class discussions were some of the best I had. Very close tight knitted group! Some of my best friends are from this class!

Cons: A lot of work! Especially for half a credit. Easily the most work out of all my classes this semester and I took some pretty hard STEM classes.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend if you want to pursue research and know nothing!

I would absolutely recommend it. While its difficult, it fosters a great sense of community within the class and it offers an unbeatable opportunity to learn about the basis of scientific research in a relevant manner.
Yes. Its a lot of work (way more than you would expect for 0.5 credits), but its a very good opportunity to enter any biology major with a strong set of highly applicable skills.
YES! Just be mindful of the amount of work required
